name: Midgard
shortDescription: The realm of humans, the Middle Earth, surrounded by ocean and connected to Asgard by the rainbow bridge Bifrost
fullDescription: Midgard (Old Norse: Mi√∞gar√∞r, meaning 'Middle Enclosure' or 'Middle Earth') is the realm of humanity in Norse cosmology, one of the Nine Realms connected by Yggdrasil. Midgard was created by Odin and his brothers from the body of the primordial giant Ymir‚Äîhis flesh became the earth, his blood the seas, his bones the mountains, his teeth the rocks, his hair the trees, and his skull the sky dome. Midgard is surrounded by a vast ocean in which dwells J√∂rmungandr, the Midgard Serpent, whose body encircles the entire realm. The first humans, Ask and Embla, were created from trees and placed in Midgard by the gods. The realm is connected to Asgard by Bifrost, the rainbow bridge, showing the relationship between gods and humans. Midgard is constantly threatened by giants (Jotnar) who seek to bring chaos, but the gods, especially Thor, protect humanity from these forces. At Ragnar√∂k, Midgard will be destroyed along with the other realms but will eventually be renewed.

geography.location: Middle level of Yggdrasil, between Asgard and Helheim

mythologyContexts.usage: Midgard represents the human realm positioned between divine order (Asgard) and chaos (Jotunheim). Its creation from Ymir's body shows that the ordered world arises from the destruction of primordial chaos. The encircling serpent J√∂rmungandr represents the boundary between cosmos and chaos, civilization and wilderness. Midgard's connection to Asgard via Bifrost shows that humanity and divinity are linked but separate. The constant threat from giants reflects human life's precarity and need for divine protection. Midgard's destruction and renewal at Ragnar√∂k teaches that even the human world participates in cosmic cycles.
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Midgard symbolizes the middle path‚Äîbetween heaven and hell, order and chaos, gods and giants. The realm's circular ocean boundary represents the limits of human knowledge and safety. The rainbow bridge to Asgard shows that humans can aspire toward the divine. Midgard's creation from a giant's body teaches that order arises from sacrifice and transformation of chaos. The protection by Thor and other gods shows humanity's dependence on divine power against chaotic forces. The term 'Middle Earth' influenced modern fantasy literature.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Midgard gave Norse people their cosmic context‚Äîneither abandoned by gods nor living in paradise, but in a middle realm requiring both human effort and divine aid. The concept shaped Norse understanding of their relationship with nature (surrounded by threatening wilderness and ocean) and with gods (connected but separate). Modern Norse paganism uses Midgard to represent Earth and environmental stewardship. Tolkien's Middle-earth draws directly from this concept. The term remains culturally significant as representing the human sphere between spiritual and chaotic realms.

etymology.derivation: From mi√∞r (middle) + gar√∞r (enclosure, yard). The world of humans, middle between gods and chaos

originPoint.name: Scandinavia (mythological human realm)
originPoint.description: The human world in Norse cosmology

historicalDate.display: Migration Period to Viking Age (400-1100 CE)
